page.title: 16LOCAL HISTORY: BUILDINGS
page.content: {Boundaries}in this ancient village, which is mentioned in the Domesday Book, are marked by hedges, fences and traditionally, Mendip dry stone walls. {Chewton Mendip}contains many{stone {built cottages.}A group of cottages, including a thatched cottage with unusual decorations,built in the mid eighteenth century can be seen at the Folly (596,527) {Manor Farm(595,529)}is the oldest original building in Chewton Mendip. The house was built in the seventeenth century and has fine mullioned windows with stone crosses. The house belongs to the Waldegrave family and is used by the manager for Waldegrave farms. {Pack horse bridge}The bridge(598,531) spans the River Chew. It lies on what was the Bristol to Wells road approximalty fifty metres east of the A39.
